metadata.chief_complaint: ear pain, parents disagree on timeline and treatment

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi everyone, I'm Dr. Chen. Sophie's here for ear pain?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Yes, she's been complaining about her ear since yesterday morning. She was up all night crying.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: Well, it wasn't all night. She woke up once around two AM.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: She was up multiple times, Mike. You just slept through it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, so it sounds like it started yesterday. Sophie, can you point to where it hurts?

script.speaker: child
script.text: Here. This ear.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: The right ear. Has she had a fever?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Yes, 101 last night. I gave her Tylenol.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I checked this morning and she was 99. That's not really a fever.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Because the Tylenol brought it down. It was definitely 101 last night.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Got it, so she did have a fever that responded to Tylenol. Any other symptoms? Runny nose, cough?

script.speaker: dad
script.text: She's had a cold for like a week. I think this is just part of the cold.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: She's had a runny nose but the ear pain is new. That's not just a cold.

script.speaker: child
script.text: My ear hurts really bad!

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I hear you, sweetie. Let me take a look and see what's going on.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay Sophie, I'm going to look in your ears with this light. Hold still for me.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Left ear looks clear. Now the right side... yeah, I can see the eardrum is red and bulging. There's fluid behind it. She does have an ear infection.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: See? I knew it. She needs antibiotics.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I read that most ear infections clear up on their own. Can't we just wait and see?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's actually a fair point. For kids over two with mild symptoms, watchful waiting is an option. But Sophie is four and she has a fever and significant pain, which makes me lean toward treating.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: She's miserable. I don't want to wait and have her suffer.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: I just don't want to give antibiotics if she doesn't need them. What about resistance and all that?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I appreciate you thinking about that. Antibiotic stewardship is important. But in this case, with the bulging eardrum and her symptoms, I do think antibiotics are appropriate. We'll use a narrow-spectrum one.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: What if we wait 24 hours and see if she improves?

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Mike, she's in pain. Why would we wait?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Here's what I'd suggest as a middle ground. I can write the prescription today. You could fill it and start tonight, or you could wait until tomorrow morning and see how she's doing. If she's significantly better, you could hold off. If she's the same or worse, start the antibiotic.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: That seems reasonable.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: I'm going to fill it and start it tonight. She needs it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's completely fine too. Either approach works. I'll send over amoxicillin, twice a day for ten days. Keep up with the Tylenol or Motrin for pain.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Is it the pink medicine? I like the pink one.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Yes, it's the pink one. You'll take it twice a day, morning and bedtime.

script.speaker: mom
script.text: Thank you, Doctor. Should we follow up?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If she's not better in three days, or if she gets worse, call us. Otherwise, you don't need a recheck unless the symptoms come back.

script.speaker: dad
script.text: Thanks. Sorry we were, uh, not on the same page.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: No apology needed. It's good that you both advocate for her. Feel better, Sophie.
